choices.A: Create a new compartment for the POC and grant appropriate permissions to create and manage resources within the compartment.
choices.B: Provision all new resources into the root compartment. Grant permissions that only allow for creation and management of resources specific to the POC.
choices.C: Provision all new resources into the root compartment. Use defined tags to separate resources that belong to different applications.
choices.D: Create a new tenancy for the POC. Provision all new resources into the root compartment. Grant appropriate permissions to create and manage resources within the root compartment.

discussion.content: It's A
Definitely A. You don't provision something you won't need in the long term into the root compartment, instead create a new compartment and when finished with it you blow it away.

D is too much.

correct A
totally A
i agree with u, A is more logically inclined to the best practice

questions.question_text:
Your company has been running several small applications in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure and is planning a proof-of-concept (POC) to deploy PeopleSoft.
If your existing resources are being maintained in the root compartment, what is the recommended approach for defining security for the upcoming POC?

choices.A: Terminate the compute instance preserving the boot volume. Create a new compute instance using a VM Dense IO shape using the boot volume preserved.
choices.D: Terminate the compute instance and create a backup of the boot volume. Create a new compute instance using a VM Dense IO shape and restore the backup.
choices.B: Terminate the compute instance preserving the boot volume. Create a new compute instance using a VM Standard shape and attach a new block volume to host your application.
choices.C: Create a backup of the boot volume. Create a new compute instance using a VM Dense IO shape and restore the backup.

discussion.content: It's A and C, you need dense shape

A & C are correct. 

- B is incorrect as it states that preserve the boot volume but didn't mention to use preserved boot volume to launch the new instance. 
- D is incorrect as it states that terminate instance and create the backup, so when instance is terminated will lose the boot volume where is in A option it mention to terminate instance by preserving the boot volume.

Correct Answer A,C
B Incorrect because the shape Is Standard which does not include SSD
D, Incorrect because they are terminating the instance and then seeking a backup.
B & C - should be the correct answer!
we can't create new instance shape based on preserved boot volume, we can only increase the size or performance while restoring

comments.content:
we can create new instance shape based on preserved boot volume.
Refer: https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Concepts/bootvolumes.htm

discussion.content:
A and C os the right answer.
You need to connect the boot volume you preserved to the new instance.

A and D
Need to terminate instance

comments.content:
No you dont need to terminate. You can make a backup of a boot volume while it is attached to a running instance, or you can make a backup of a boot volume while it is detached from the instance.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Concepts/bootvolumebackups.htm
Answer is A and C.

if you don't need to terminate why A is correct.
If u have to switch the instance, it's better to terminate it.
If you terminate by default it delete the boot volume

questions.question_text:
You have an application running on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. You identified that the read and write operations are slowing your application down enough to impair user access. The application is currently using a VM.Standard1.2 compute without any block storage attached to it.
Which two options allow you to increase disk performance? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Create a DR environment in Ashburn and provision a FastConnect virtual circuit using DRG between the regions.
choices.A: Create a new virtual cloud network (VCN) in the Phoenix region and create a subnet in one availability domain (AD) that is not currently being used by your production systems. Establish VCN peering between the production and DR sites.
choices.D: Create a DR environment in Ashburn. Associate a dynamic routing gateway (DRG) with the VCN in each region and configure an IPsec VPN connection between the two regions.
choices.B: Create a DR environment in Ashburn. Associate a DRG with the VCN in each region and create a remote peering connection between the two VCNs.

questions.question_text:
You have an application deployed in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure running only in the Phoenix region. You were asked to create a disaster recovery (DR) plan that will protect against the loss of critical data. The DR site must be at least 500 miles from your primary site and data transfer between the two sites must not traverse the public internet.
Which is the recommended disaster recovery plan?

discussion.content:
A is wrong, it's likely not 500 miles away.
B is correct, it's the only option that allows for traffic flow without traversing the internet.
C is incorrect, FastConnect is for on-prem/provider connectivity to the Cloud.
D is incorrect, VPN connection is via the internet.
I would go with B. You need a DRG, remote peer the two environments. There was something exactly like this in the official practise test
It's B. Why do I need to create another subnet?
Agree b
B is the right answer. Saw it in the practice test
answer - B

choices.A: Terminate the instance while preserving the boot volume. Create a new instance from the boot volume and select a DenseIO shape to take advantage of local NVMe storage.
choices.C: Create and attach a block volume to the compute instance and copy the log files.
choices.D: Create a custom image and launch a new compute instance with a larger boot volume size.
choices.B: Create an object storage bucket and use a script that runs daily to move log files older than 15 days to the bucket.
choices.E: Write a custom script to remove the log files on a daily basis and free up the space on the boot volume.

questions.question_text:
You have multiple applications installed on a compute instance and these applications generate a large amount of log files. These log files must reside on the boot volume for a minimum of 15 days and must be retained for at least 60 days. The 60-day retention requirement is causing an issue with available disk space.
What are the two recommended methods to provide additional boot volume space for this compute instance? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I think it is B and D
B&E, ,n E you are removing the files older than 60 days

C has no sense. It's not clear the dimension of the new boot volume and the instance can have only one.

B D

B, D
A: no — DenseIO is not for space, is for performance
C: no — if you copy the log files to block volume, you still have a copy of the logs files on the boot volume, so you are not freeing up space
E: remove the logs that you are suppoused to keep for 60 days? not good idea.

A - overkill
C - wrong. Copy the log files doesn't release the disk space in boot volume. Move operation does that.
D - wrong. Can resize and change the volume performance of the attached boot volume. Not necessary to create a new instance.

Answer: B, E

comments.content:
Hmmmm not sure. You don't like C because it doesn't mention removing the logs, but you like E which says "to remove the logs", which since it doesn't mention any time constraint would mean deleting all logs.
I would go for B&C

discussion.content: B and d
I think C and D. B is a bit overkill to me.
B & C looks good to me!

comments.content: C says copy.That means the log files are still in the boot volume occupying the disk space.
Agree. Besides that, you can resize and change the volume performance of the attached boot volume. Not necessary to create a new instance.
The last part of the questions mentions "this instance", with "D" you end up with a new one

discussion.content: D not for sure

comments.content: logs file must reside on boot volume , how you would move them to attached disks?

discussion.content: answer - c & d

questions.question_text: Which two statements about file storage service (FSS) are accurate? (Choose two.)

comments.content: D says "within the same subnet"...how can we use security list here?, you must use NSG. This answer has to be wrong.

discussion.content:
A is correct for sure. Second, I would go with D. 

At this time data-at-rest is encrypted, soon oracle will provide in-transit encryption.

A and D are correct. Data in-transit is not enabled by default.
 https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Tasks/intransitencryption.htm
Encryption is applied to the file system not mount target. So, the answers are A & D.
Answer is A,D. Data at rest and in trasit to an FSS mount file system is encrypted not mount target.

Data in-transit encryption is not enabled by default and you have to install oci-fss-utils package in the Instance 

Reference: https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Tasks/intransitencryption.htm?Highlight=oci-fss-utils

So A and D is correct.
FSS supports both data at rest and in-transit encryption for all file systems and meta data. Ans should be D and E
D and e for me

Encryption in transit can be configured but not enabled by default https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Tasks/intransitencryption.htm
D is technically correct , but would someone give access to whole subnet from FSS side and configure rules for FSS for individual instances from security list side , Instead of simply adding individual instances IPs to Mount targets
E is NOT for sure
I think A and E are correct: https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Concepts/filestorageoverview.htm

comments.content: sorry I would say A and D, data are encrypted at rest, not in transit
Deny word is not used. It says "Virtual firewall to prevent" , i.e allowing only required instance access. https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Concepts/filestorageoverview.htm
Why D? There is no way to set DENY rule in security list. Everything is denied unless explicitly ALLOW in the security list. Anyone?

discussion.content: Answer is D,E

choices.A: FSS leverages UNIX user group and permission checking for file access security
choices.B: Encryption of file system in FSS is optional
choices.E: Data in transit to an FSS mount target is encrypted
choices.C: Identity and Access Management (IAM) controls which file systems are mountable by which instances
choices.D: Security lists can be used as a virtual firewall to prevent an instance from mounting an FSS mount target within the same subnet
